abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Livestock Waste Management in East Asia Project for East
            Asia and Pacific to demonstrate replicable and sustainable
            livestock waste management approaches that will protect and
            improve the local and global environment while enhancing
            livelihoods, particularly in public health. The Governments
            of China (Guangdong Province), Thailand and Vietnam have
            applied for the Global Environment Facility (GEF) grant for
            support to promote livestock waste management in respective
            countries to address the regional pollution problems from
            increased growth and intensification of livestock industry
            in the project countries. This environmental assessment
            identifies potential environmental risks and proposes
            measures to mitigate them. Temporary negative impacts,
            believed to be minor, include: vegetation damage during
            lagoon, or constructed wetland development for the
            establishment of treatment facilities; temporary land
            occupation at the construction sites; potential soil erosion
            and corresponding increase in sediment load during
            construction; and noise, air, and water pollution. Other
            impacts expected during operation include: impact on water
            resources (surface and groundwater due to percolation from
            the bottom of lagoons, breakage of lagoon embankments (above
            ground lagoons), overflow due to incidence of high intensity
            rainfall lagoon capacity; soil pollution through improper
            application of solid and liquid manure; explosion of biogas
            tanks; overproduction of solid and liquid manure and lack of
            available land or farmer willingness to apply the manure on
            agricultural land, forcing direct discharge of partially
            treated manure to surface water bodies; cumulative impact
            from large manure treatment system (eutrophication, increase
            in COD, coli forms, etc.); and potential health effects from
            pathogens and parasites through the application of solid and
            liquid manure. Mitigation measures include: watershed
            management; applying best management practices and improving
            enforcement in livestock manure treatment systems; and
            control of point and non-point source pollution of water resources.
